body:
Just spit-balling, but...

I do not think God necessarily anticipated the rejection of Christ until the coming days to His crucifixion.  I'm sure in the back of His mind (If I can personify) He may have believed it would happen based on past events of the Jewish elite constantly rejecting him and confounding His true nature...

So, His failsafe was to open the Kingdom to everyone since His people rejected Him in His pure form and establish the Church.  His 2nd coming would be in the hopes that Israel would repent for a crucified and risen Messiah. (I do not think that the Jews will accept Him even still, especially those Jesus calls "fake Jews")

BUT, if they had accepted him, then I truly believe the reign of a thousand years would have begun then and there.

Anyway, lemme know your thoughts.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
How would he not have known about this? Is he not omniscient?

And remember despite what blasphemous scribes like Ezra claim about the "holy race" the old testament is full of promises to "all the world". And in fact Adam & Eve, Noah, Lot, and arguably Abraham were also not Jewish themselves, and yet it was still open to them, thousands of years before The Annointed One.

body:
Yea, I don't think Judaism necessarily began until Moses.  It's beginnings were Henotheistic in its recognition of other gods.

But to speak of Noah, Lot, and Abraham, I believe they were visited by a pre-incarnate Christ - Melchizedek and blessed.

post.title: What if Israel had repented and accepted Christ as Messiah during His mission?

body: God doesn't make mistakes or play dice. Otherwise, He is not God. God gave us The Son knowing full well His wisdom would become His sacrifice. I think the correct interpretation is that to be the revolutionary hero (in other words, to live like Jesus), you can expect to pay a dear sacrifice for imparting new knowledge and wisdom (in other words, revelations) to the people. That's kind of what a revelation means. For Israel to just accept Jesus, his teachings would have to be more or less in line with their pre-existing beliefs, which would make Jesus not a Messiah.
body_html: God doesn't make mistakes or play dice. Otherwise, He is not God. God gave us The Son knowing full well His wisdom would become His sacrifice. Just spit-balling, but...

I do not think God necessarily anticipated the rejection of Christ until the coming days to His crucifixion.  I'm sure in the back of His mind (If I can personify) He may have believed it would happen based on past events of the Jewish elite constantly rejecting him and confounding His true nature...

So, His failsafe was to open the Kingdom to everyone since His people rejected Him in His pure form and establish the Church.  His 2nd coming would be in the hopes that Israel would repent for a crucified and risen Messiah. (I do not think that the Jews will accept Him even still, especially those Jesus calls "fake Jews")

BUT, if they had accepted him, then I truly believe the reign of a thousand years would have begun then and there.

Anyway, lemme know your thoughts.

body:
> It's beginnings were Henotheistic in its recognition of other gods.

That is not the real beginning. If you recall correctly paganism and idol worship was a constant problem in the old testament. Those very same gods that were so prevalent that historians think they were the original religion: El, Baal, Asherah, etc. are exactly the ones the prophets in the old testament constantly complain about people worshiping. The paganism in the Torah is not a good indicator, because it has been heavily edited by the lying pen of scribes, many of whom were those same pagans.

> But to speak of Noah, Lot, and Abraham, I believe they were visited by a pre-incarnate Christ - Melchizedek and blessed.

But if it was originally only meant for the Jewish people, why would they have been blessed?
body_html:
It's beginnings were Henotheistic in its recognition of other gods.

That is not the real beginning. If you recall correctly paganism and idol worship was a constant problem in the old testament. Those very same gods that were so prevalent that historians think they were the original religion: El, Baal, Asherah, etc. are exactly the ones the prophets in the old testament constantly complain about people worshiping. The paganism in the Torah is not a good indicator, because it has been heavily edited by the lying pen of scribes, many of whom were those same pagans.

But to speak of Noah, Lot, and Abraham, I believe they were visited by a pre-incarnate Christ - Melchizedek and blessed.

But if it was originally only meant for the Jewish people, why would they have been blessed?

parent.body: God doesn't make mistakes or play dice. Otherwise, He is not God. God gave us The Son knowing full well His wisdom would become His sacrifice. I think the correct interpretation is that to be the revolutionary hero (in other words, to live like Jesus), you can expect to pay a dear sacrifice for imparting new knowledge and wisdom (in other words, revelations) to the people. That's kind of what a revelation means. For Israel to just accept Jesus, his teachings would have to be more or less in line with their pre-existing beliefs, which would make Jesus not a Messiah.

post.title: What if Israel had repented and accepted Christ as Messiah during His mission?

body:
Isaiah predicted the coming of Christ. Isaiah told the Israelites that God would use Jesus to bring the Gentiles to worship God.

Isaiah does say this as he condemns the Israelites. But it seems to me that he doesn't say that he means to say that the Israelites don't hold their laws well enough. He says that the Israelites don't feed the world with the grace of God, and it makes God hate their supposed acts of "obedience".

Isaiah says that the Israelites will be punished but the savior of the Gentiles will eventually bring kings of all nations to bring treasures to Jerusalem in honor of God. The Israelites thought that God would send a savior to enslave the nations of the world to Israel. But that's retarded because God frees Israel from the Egyptians and told them not to take slaves (he told them to slaughter their enemies).

God had planned for the Israelites to be idiots because ALL people are like this because of the fall of man. But we know that God had a plan for the Edomites when he blessed Esau from birth, but less so than Jacob.

God always had a plan to bless the Gentiles. And Isaiah actually speaks that the Gentiles may end up being blessed more in some circumstances than the Israelites, but that the treasures of the Gentiles would provide for Jerusalem as the city of Zion. The Gentiles would become an extension of God's hands as the Israelites were prior to Jesus.

Remember also that not all Israelites were the children of David, and God specifically seeks to bless the children of David because he promised his servant David that his kin would rule the world. That was the tribe of Judah, which was kept in Jerusalem while the rest of the tribes were scattered. But he told Judah that while Judah would be preserved, it would always be a lesser power on God's Earth. Always subservient to Israelites elsewhere. It's why Jerusalem is still a lesser power riding on the coattails of other Christian nations. And other Christian nations provide their treaures to build the walls of Jerusalem.

But as God said to Judah, they would be amongst the most rebellious people to God. They would be regarded as corrupted silver.

The Bible don't lie, bruh. God knows everything and tells us.

I do not think God necessarily anticipated the rejection of Christ until the coming days to His crucifixion. So, His failsafe was to open the Kingdom to everyone since His people rejected Him in His pure form and establish the Church.  His 2nd coming would be in the hopes that Israel would repent for a crucified and risen Messiah. (I do not think that the Jews will accept Him even still, especially those Jesus calls "fake Jews")

BUT, if they had accepted him, then I truly believe the reign of a thousand years would have begun then and there.

Anyway, lemme know your thoughts.

body:
Good explanation, but I had a few concerns:

> he told them to slaughter their enemies

He almost certainly didn't say that either, that story is a bunch of bullshit made up by scribes, as is much of the Pentateuch. In fact the real promised land may have been the desert all along, can't God just send food and supplies to rain down on them, and rocks to burst open with water like he did?

> Remember also that not all Israelites were the children of David, and God specifically seeks to bless the children of David because he promised his servant David that his kin would rule the world.

If I'm not mistaken that is about Jesus, not people of a particular family tree.

> The Bible don't lie

If it doesn't lie, then why did God warn about it doing so?

"How can you say, 'we are wise, and the law of 𐤉𐤄𐤅𐤄 is with us' when in reality the lying pen of scribes wrote to deceive?" - Jeremiah 8:8, Masoretic Text
body_html:
Good explanation, but I had a few concerns:

he told them to slaughter their enemies

He almost certainly didn't say that either, that story is a bunch of bullshit made up by scribes, as is much of the Pentateuch. Remember also that not all Israelites were the children of David, and God specifically seeks to bless the children of David because he promised his servant David that his kin would rule the world.

If I'm not mistaken that is about Jesus, not people of a particular family tree.

The Bible don't lie

"How can you say, 'we are wise, and the law of 𐤉𐤄𐤅𐤄 is with us' when in reality the lying pen of scribes wrote to deceive?" - Jeremiah 8:8, Masoretic Text

parent.body:
Isaiah predicted the coming of Christ. Isaiah told the Israelites that God would use Jesus to bring the Gentiles to worship God.

Isaiah does say this as he condemns the Israelites. But it seems to me that he doesn't say that he means to say that the Israelites don't hold their laws well enough. He says that the Israelites don't feed the world with the grace of God, and it makes God hate their supposed acts of "obedience".

Isaiah says that the Israelites will be punished but the savior of the Gentiles will eventually bring kings of all nations to bring treasures to Jerusalem in honor of God. The Israelites thought that God would send a savior to enslave the nations of the world to Israel. But that's retarded because God frees Israel from the Egyptians and told them not to take slaves (he told them to slaughter their enemies).

God had planned for the Israelites to be idiots because ALL people are like this because of the fall of man. But we know that God had a plan for the Edomites when he blessed Esau from birth, but less so than Jacob.

God always had a plan to bless the Gentiles. And Isaiah actually speaks that the Gentiles may end up being blessed more in some circumstances than the Israelites, but that the treasures of the Gentiles would provide for Jerusalem as the city of Zion. The Gentiles would become an extension of God's hands as the Israelites were prior to Jesus.

Remember also that not all Israelites were the children of David, and God specifically seeks to bless the children of David because he promised his servant David that his kin would rule the world. That was the tribe of Judah, which was kept in Jerusalem while the rest of the tribes were scattered. But he told Judah that while Judah would be preserved, it would always be a lesser power on God's Earth. Always subservient to Israelites elsewhere. It's why Jerusalem is still a lesser power riding on the coattails of other Christian nations. And other Christian nations provide their treaures to build the walls of Jerusalem.

But as God said to Judah, they would be amongst the most rebellious people to God. They would be regarded as corrupted silver.

The Bible don't lie, bruh. God knows everything and tells us.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

post.body:
Just spit-balling, but...

I do not think God necessarily anticipated the rejection of Christ until the coming days to His crucifixion.  I'm sure in the back of His mind (If I can personify) He may have believed it would happen based on past events of the Jewish elite constantly rejecting him and confounding His true nature...

So, His failsafe was to open the Kingdom to everyone since His people rejected Him in His pure form and establish the Church.  His 2nd coming would be in the hopes that Israel would repent for a crucified and risen Messiah. (I do not think that the Jews will accept Him even still, especially those Jesus calls "fake Jews")

BUT, if they had accepted him, then I truly believe the reign of a thousand years would have begun then and there.

Anyway, lemme know your thoughts.

body:
Well, in a sense it's God's plan. The old testament lays out the specific Earthly punishment for various behaviors in society that go against God. But since the ood testament lays out the punishments for the sins of society, God warned us in advance. You don't have to like the rules, just like you have no choice about the laws of nature.

The Israelites were in a situation somewhat like what the West is facing today. The people who perpetrated the defiance to God even had their kids enslaved. But God also delivered his followers from Sodom and Gomorrah.

post.title: What if Israel had repented and accepted Christ as Messiah during His mission?

body:
God told them that when they conquer that they must kill everyone. He didn't say that they should always conquer. So you are right about that. When the Israelites went to conquer without God's command, they were totally defeated.

In the kin of David, God was talking about Jesus. But before Jesus, God specifically blessed the tribe of Judah to prepare the way for Jesus.

And jeremiah was a rebuke to the Israelite society at that time. It comes after Isaiah, who also calls out the sins of Israel. The point there is that the official scribes of the time were claiming to interpet God's law from his Word. This in itself is fine, as God helps us divine his message. But many of the scribes were not actually trying to listen to God. They instead were interpreting God's laws based upon their Earthly political goals.

God makes it easy to see whether a part of the Bible is a lie. The Bible has an innumerable set of themes, rules, and wisdom that run throughout. If something is necessarily contrary to what happens on Earth or what God promises, then it's fake.

Jeremiah could see that the scribes were making shit up, and therefore so could other people. Each part of the Bible has been vetted by centuries or millenia of theological scholarship, and they would not perpetuate things that don't comport with God. If you read it, you'll see that anything that you have come to realize as truth about humanity and nature is already written in the Bible, so it's derived from Truth and not temporary political desires.

parent.body:
Good explanation, but I had a few concerns:

> he told them to slaughter their enemies

He almost certainly didn't say that either, that story is a bunch of bullshit made up by scribes, as is much of the Pentateuch. In fact the real promised land may have been the desert all along, can't God just send food and supplies to rain down on them, and rocks to burst open with water like he did?

> Remember also that not all Israelites were the children of David, and God specifically seeks to bless the children of David because he promised his servant David that his kin would rule the world.

If I'm not mistaken that is about Jesus, not people of a particular family tree.

> The Bible don't lie

If it doesn't lie, then why did God warn about it doing so?

"How can you say, 'we are wise, and the law of 𐤉𐤄𐤅𐤄 is with us' when in reality the lying pen of scribes wrote to deceive?" - Jeremiah 8:8, Masoretic Text
parent.body_html:
Good explanation, but I had a few concerns:

he told them to slaughter their enemies

He almost certainly didn't say that either, that story is a bunch of bullshit made up by scribes, as is much of the Pentateuch. In fact the real promised land may have been the desert all along, can't God just send food and supplies to rain down on them, and rocks to burst open with water like he did?

Remember also that not all Israelites were the children of David, and God specifically seeks to bless the children of David because he promised his servant David that his kin would rule the world.

If I'm not mistaken that is about Jesus, not people of a particular family tree.

The Bible don't lie

If it doesn't lie, then why did God warn about it doing so?

"How can you say, 'we are wise, and the law of 𐤉𐤄𐤅𐤄 is with us' when in reality the lying pen of scribes wrote to deceive?" - Jeremiah 8:8, Masoretic Text

body:
> God told them that when they conquer that they must kill everyone. He didn't say that they should always conquer. So you are right about that. When the Israelites went to conquer without God's command, they were totally defeated.

This is probably a story made up later. There's no evidence this ever happened, and it doesn't sound like God at all, but it does sound like a tale that a scribe living in ancient times with a racial-centric worldview would find fascinating. Especially if it was written down decades or centuries after the fact, it would've been exaggerated quite a lot. This isn't to say they never conquered anything, only that the genocide part is an exaggeration, and I personally think it's quite likely God didn't actually tell them to conquer anything, they had their own idea.

> And jeremiah was a rebuke to the Israelite society at that time. It comes after Isaiah, who also calls out the sins of Israel. The point there is that the official scribes of the time were claiming to interpet God's law from his Word. This in itself is fine, as God helps us divine his message. But many of the scribes were not actually trying to listen to God. They instead were interpreting God's laws based upon their Earthly political goals.

To my knowledge this was a later development. In Jeremiah's time scribes were only responsible for copying text; the priests interpreted. Also note how it says they do not have the law, and the reason they don't have it because the scribes were dishonest. Interesting how this is right after Josiah's priests "found" a lost book of law in the temple (wow, such a sacred text with only one copy and was misplaced and forgotten about) which conveniently gave him more power and introduced laws just in time for him to implement his desired reforms. And at the time of the Levitical priesthood who forged phony books like Leviticus and made up laws such as non-Levites being priests were not allowed, with the penalty of being stoned to death, even though David's family, half Moabites, had been priests and no one noticed. If you still aren't convinced, read Jeremiah 7:1-8:8, God condemns some of the practices of these people, and some of them are clearly commanded in the Torah. This finishes off with the comment about the lying pen of scribes. You might want to take a look at the original Hebrew for this one, because most translations are dishonest here. And reread the commandment to sacrifice and tell me "savory aroma" doesn't sound completely pagan and sadistic.

> God makes it easy to see whether a part of the Bible is a lie. The Bible has an innumerable set of themes, rules, and wisdom that run throughout. If something is necessarily contrary to what happens on Earth or what God promises, then it's fake.

The bible contradicts itself thousands of times because of the scribes changing it to suit their agendas. Well also because we for some reason consider random writings by people to be authoritative, and different people have different ideas. [Here's a huge list](https://infidels.org/library/modern/donald_morgan/contradictions.html), a lot of them are bs with an agenda to disprove it, but you have to admit some of them are really there.

> Jeremiah could see that the scribes were making shit up, and therefore so could other people. Each part of the Bible has been vetted by centuries or millenia of theological scholarship, and they would not perpetuate things that don't comport with God. If you read it, you'll see that anything that you have come to realize as truth about humanity and nature is already written in the Bible, so it's derived from Truth and not temporary political desires.

Just because it has truth in it doesn't make *all* of it true. For starters, the Protestant Bible consists of 66 separate books. All of them have scribal edits, some more so than others. Some are mistakes, others are an attempt to avoid confusion in a difficult passage, and others are deliberate changes. Many of them are nothing more than works by popular authors throughout history, and they don't always agree. Some are forgeries. In my opinion the synoptic gospels are the purest books we have, although they still have a few edits.

Well also because we for some reason consider random writings by people to be authoritative, and different people have different ideas. Here's a huge list, a lot of them are bs with an agenda to disprove it, but you have to admit some of them are really there.

Jeremiah could see that the scribes were making shit up, and therefore so could other people. Each part of the Bible has been vetted by centuries or millenia of theological scholarship, and they would not perpetuate things that don't comport with God. If you read it, you'll see that anything that you have come to realize as truth about humanity and nature is already written in the Bible, so it's derived from Truth and not temporary political desires.

Just because it has truth in it doesn't make all of it true. For starters, the Protestant Bible consists of 66 separate books. All of them have scribal edits, some more so than others. Some are mistakes, others are an attempt to avoid confusion in a difficult passage, and others are deliberate changes. Many of them are nothing more than works by popular authors throughout history, and they don't always agree. Some are forgeries. In my opinion the synoptic gospels are the purest books we have, although they still have a few edits.

body:
I don't know why you think Leviticus is lies. The medical and sanitation processes in that book were not surpassed in modern science until the 20th century. If the scribes were lying, how is it so accurate with cause and effect?

Numbers also has incredible legal standards that were more progressive than legal standards maybe even now.

And just reading through the first couple "inconsistencies" in your list there, I can tell it was either compiled dishonestly or by someone pretty stupid. I'll go over the first two just to give you an example. I can do others you think are valid.

When God created light and darkness, it was amorphous, acorporeal light and darkness. God did not create specific celestial bodies that are a source of natural light such as the sun and moon until later. There are two messages here: one is that light does not need to come from the sun, and you know this because you get a lot of light from eletrified metal filaments. Magma casts a cool red glow. The other message is that if your God is a sun god, that wasn't even the first thing god created. The light that God brings is bigger than the sun.

The second "inconsistency" is that supposedly man plants the trees that God created before man. If you read, that's clearly not what is said. In the second part, God is talking about the "plants of the field" meaning crops in a tended field or garden. And when God says that the man will plant trees, he says that the man will plant trees which "are pleasing in his sight", meaning that man does not plant all trees. Man only plants trees which he likes, and he gets to choose from all of the trees that God already planted before God created man.

Any others that you think are actual inconsistencies? I would ask that you read them yourself first because I would assume you to be either as dishonest or dumb as the original author if you just pushed everything they list.

parent.body:
> God told them that when they conquer that they must kill everyone. He didn't say that they should always conquer. So you are right about that. When the Israelites went to conquer without God's command, they were totally defeated.

This is probably a story made up later. There's no evidence this ever happened, and it doesn't sound like God at all, but it does sound like a tale that a scribe living in ancient times with a racial-centric worldview would find fascinating. Especially if it was written down decades or centuries after the fact, it would've been exaggerated quite a lot. This isn't to say they never conquered anything, only that the genocide part is an exaggeration, and I personally think it's quite likely God didn't actually tell them to conquer anything, they had their own idea.

> And jeremiah was a rebuke to the Israelite society at that time. It comes after Isaiah, who also calls out the sins of Israel. The point there is that the official scribes of the time were claiming to interpet God's law from his Word. This in itself is fine, as God helps us divine his message. But many of the scribes were not actually trying to listen to God. They instead were interpreting God's laws based upon their Earthly political goals.

To my knowledge this was a later development. In Jeremiah's time scribes were only responsible for copying text; the priests interpreted. Also note how it says they do not have the law, and the reason they don't have it because the scribes were dishonest. Interesting how this is right after Josiah's priests "found" a lost book of law in the temple (wow, such a sacred text with only one copy and was misplaced and forgotten about) which conveniently gave him more power and introduced laws just in time for him to implement his desired reforms. And at the time of the Levitical priesthood who forged phony books like Leviticus and made up laws such as non-Levites being priests were not allowed, with the penalty of being stoned to death, even though David's family, half Moabites, had been priests and no one noticed. If you still aren't convinced, read Jeremiah 7:1-8:8, God condemns some of the practices of these people, and some of them are clearly commanded in the Torah. This finishes off with the comment about the lying pen of scribes. You might want to take a look at the original Hebrew for this one, because most translations are dishonest here. And reread the commandment to sacrifice and tell me "savory aroma" doesn't sound completely pagan and sadistic.

> God makes it easy to see whether a part of the Bible is a lie. The Bible has an innumerable set of themes, rules, and wisdom that run throughout. If something is necessarily contrary to what happens on Earth or what God promises, then it's fake.

The bible contradicts itself thousands of times because of the scribes changing it to suit their agendas. Well also because we for some reason consider random writings by people to be authoritative, and different people have different ideas. [Here's a huge list](https://infidels.org/library/modern/donald_morgan/contradictions.html), a lot of them are bs with an agenda to disprove it, but you have to admit some of them are really there.

> Jeremiah could see that the scribes were making shit up, and therefore so could other people. Each part of the Bible has been vetted by centuries or millenia of theological scholarship, and they would not perpetuate things that don't comport with God. If you read it, you'll see that anything that you have come to realize as truth about humanity and nature is already written in the Bible, so it's derived from Truth and not temporary political desires.

Just because it has truth in it doesn't make *all* of it true. For starters, the Protestant Bible consists of 66 separate books. All of them have scribal edits, some more so than others. Some are mistakes, others are an attempt to avoid confusion in a difficult passage, and others are deliberate changes. Many of them are nothing more than works by popular authors throughout history, and they don't always agree. Some are forgeries. In my opinion the synoptic gospels are the purest books we have, although they still have a few edits.

body:
> I don't know why you think Leviticus is lies. The medical and sanitation processes in that book were not surpassed in modern science until the 20th century. If the scribes were lying, how is it so accurate with cause and effect?

People knew that from experience. And perhaps God really *did* warn them about it, but they turned into bullshit about ritual purity. And that's just for the clean and unclean laws, we also have animal sacrifices (keep in mind, it specifically says this was done to appease God with the "savory aroma", which is a pagan concept), genocide, brutal execution for petty reasons, stories about celebrating over chopping off peoples' fingers and toes, and all sorts of crazy stuff.

> And just reading through the first couple "inconsistencies" in your list there, I can tell it was either compiled dishonestly or by someone pretty stupid. I'll go over the first two just to give you an example. I can do others you think are valid.

I already told you that. I'll list some of them:

GE 12:7, 17:1, 18:1, 26:2, 32:30, EX 3:16, 6:2-3, 24:9-11, 33:11, NU 12:7-8, 14:14, JB 42:5, AM 7:7-8, 9:1 God is seen.    
EX 33:20, JN 1:18, 1JN 4:12 God is not seen. No one can see God's face and live. No one has ever seen him.

GE 15:9, EX 20:24, 29:10-42, LE 1:1-7:38, NU 28:1-29:40, God details sacrificial offerings.    
JE 7:21-22 God says he did no such thing.

GE 17:15-16, 20:11-12, 22:17 Abraham and his half sister, Sarai, are married and receive God's blessings.    
LE 20:17, DT 27:20-23 Incest is wrong.

EX 9:3-6 God destroys all the cattle (including horses) belonging to the Egyptians.    
EX 9:9-11 The people and the cattle are afflicted with boils.    
EX 12:12, 29 All the first-born of the cattle of the Egyptians are destroyed.    
EX 14:9 After having all their cattle destroyed, then afflicted with boils, and then their first-born cattle destroyed, the Egyptians pursue Moses on horseback.    
*Note: This is a good example of how the Pentateuch was compiled from multiple different sources.*

EX 20:5, 34:7, NU 14:18, DT 5:9, IS 14:21-22 Children are to suffer for their parent's sins.    
DT 24:16, EZ 18:19-20 Children are not to suffer for their parent's sins.

EX 20:8-11, 31:15-17, 35:1-3 No work is to be done on the Sabbath, not even lighting a fire. The commandment is permanent, and death is required for infractions.    
MK 2:27-28 Jesus says that the Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath (after his disciples were criticized for breaking the Sabbath).    
RO 14:5, CN 2:14-16 Paul says the Sabbath commandment was temporary, and to decide for yourself regarding its observance.

EX 21:23-25, LE 24:20, DT 19:21 A life for a life, an eye for an eye, etc.    
MT 5:38-44, LK 6:27-29 Turn the other cheek. Love your enemies.

EX 34:6-7, HE 9:27 God remembers sin, even when it has been forgiven.    
JE 31:34 God does not remember sin when it has been forgiven.

LE 3:17 God himself prohibits forever the eating of blood and fat.    
MT 15:11, CN 2:20-22 Jesus and Paul say that such rules don't matter--they are only human injunctions.

NU 30:2 God enjoins the making of vows (oaths).    
MT 5:33-37 Jesus forbids doing so, saying that they arise from evil (or the Devil).

DT 23:1 A castrate may not enter the assembly of the Lord.    
IS 56:4-5 Some castrates will receive special rewards.

DT 23:1 A castrate may not enter the assembly of the Lord.    
MT 19:12 Men are encouraged to consider making themselves castrates for the sake of the Kingdom of God.

There are thousands of contradictions and I can't possibly list them all. But these were the ones that stuck out to me.

GE 12:7, 17:1, 18:1, 26:2, 32:30, EX 3:16, 6:2-3, 24:9-11, 33:11, NU 12:7-8, 14:14, JB 42:5, AM 7:7-8, 9:1 God is seen. EX 33:20, JN 1:18, 1JN 4:12 God is not seen. No one can see God's face and live. No one has ever seen him.

GE 15:9, EX 20:24, 29:10-42, LE 1:1-7:38, NU 28:1-29:40, God details sacrificial offerings. JE 7:21-22 God says he did no such thing.

GE 17:15-16, 20:11-12, 22:17 Abraham and his half sister, Sarai, are married and receive God's blessings. LE 20:17, DT 27:20-23 Incest is wrong.

EX 9:3-6 God destroys all the cattle (including horses) belonging to the Egyptians. EX 9:9-11 The people and the cattle are afflicted with boils. EX 12:12, 29 All the first-born of the cattle of the Egyptians are destroyed. EX 14:9 After having all their cattle destroyed, then afflicted with boils, and then their first-born cattle destroyed, the Egyptians pursue Moses on horseback. Note: This is a good example of how the Pentateuch was compiled from multiple different sources.

EX 20:5, 34:7, NU 14:18, DT 5:9, IS 14:21-22 Children are to suffer for their parent's sins. DT 24:16, EZ 18:19-20 Children are not to suffer for their parent's sins.

EX 20:8-11, 31:15-17, 35:1-3 No work is to be done on the Sabbath, not even lighting a fire. The commandment is permanent, and death is required for infractions. MK 2:27-28 Jesus says that the Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath (after his disciples were criticized for breaking the Sabbath). RO 14:5, CN 2:14-16 Paul says the Sabbath commandment was temporary, and to decide for yourself regarding its observance.

EX 21:23-25, LE 24:20, DT 19:21 A life for a life, an eye for an eye, etc. MT 5:38-44, LK 6:27-29 Turn the other cheek. Love your enemies.

EX 34:6-7, HE 9:27 God remembers sin, even when it has been forgiven. JE 31:34 God does not remember sin when it has been forgiven.

LE 3:17 God himself prohibits forever the eating of blood and fat. MT 15:11, CN 2:20-22 Jesus and Paul say that such rules don't matter--they are only human injunctions.

NU 30:2 God enjoins the making of vows (oaths). MT 5:33-37 Jesus forbids doing so, saying that they arise from evil (or the Devil).

DT 23:1 A castrate may not enter the assembly of the Lord. IS 56:4-5 Some castrates will receive special rewards.

DT 23:1 A castrate may not enter the assembly of the Lord. MT 19:12 Men are encouraged to consider making themselves castrates for the sake of the Kingdom of God.

There are thousands of contradictions and I can't possibly list them all. But these were the ones that stuck out to me.

But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

parent.body:
I don't know why you think Leviticus is lies. The medical and sanitation processes in that book were not surpassed in modern science until the 20th century. If the scribes were lying, how is it so accurate with cause and effect?

Numbers also has incredible legal standards that were more progressive than legal standards maybe even now.

And just reading through the first couple "inconsistencies" in your list there, I can tell it was either compiled dishonestly or by someone pretty stupid. I'll go over the first two just to give you an example. I can do others you think are valid.

When God created light and darkness, it was amorphous, acorporeal light and darkness. God did not create specific celestial bodies that are a source of natural light such as the sun and moon until later. There are two messages here: one is that light does not need to come from the sun, and you know this because you get a lot of light from eletrified metal filaments. Magma casts a cool red glow. The other message is that if your God is a sun god, that wasn't even the first thing god created. The light that God brings is bigger than the sun.

The second "inconsistency" is that supposedly man plants the trees that God created before man. If you read, that's clearly not what is said. In the second part, God is talking about the "plants of the field" meaning crops in a tended field or garden. And when God says that the man will plant trees, he says that the man will plant trees which "are pleasing in his sight", meaning that man does not plant all trees. Man only plants trees which he likes, and he gets to choose from all of the trees that God already planted before God created man.

Any others that you think are actual inconsistencies? I would ask that you read them yourself first because I would assume you to be either as dishonest or dumb as the original author if you just pushed everything they list.

post.body:
Just spit-balling, but...

I do not think God necessarily anticipated the rejection of Christ until the coming days to His crucifixion.  I'm sure in the back of His mind (If I can personify) He may have believed it would happen based on past events of the Jewish elite constantly rejecting him and confounding His true nature...

So, His failsafe was to open the Kingdom to everyone since His people rejected Him in His pure form and establish the Church.  His 2nd coming would be in the hopes that Israel would repent for a crucified and risen Messiah. (I do not think that the Jews will accept Him even still, especially those Jesus calls "fake Jews")

BUT, if they had accepted him, then I truly believe the reign of a thousand years would have begun then and there.

Anyway, lemme know your thoughts.
